questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Digit Repetition Test?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to assess long-term memory.

options.label: B
options.text: The average digit span for adults is 10–12 digits.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a measure of attention and working memory.

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot differentiate between organic and functional disorders.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a measure of attention and working memory.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Digit Repetition Test (also known as the Digit Span Test)
  • ➤ During the test, the examiner recites a series of numbers, and the patient is required to repeat them back. The test begins with a single digit and gradually progresses to longer sequences (e.g. two-digit, three-digit, etc.) until the patient is unable to accurately repeat the numbers. An inability to repeat at least five digits indicates defective attention. E.g. If the examiner says 1,4,2,6,9; the patient should be able to repeat and say 1,4,2,6,9. A variation is the digit backward test, where if the examiner says 1,4,2,6,9; the patient is supposed to say 9,6,2,4,1, can also be used. Digit repetition test (digit forward test) is preferred over digit backward test.
  • ➤ During the test, the examiner recites a series of numbers, and the patient is required to repeat them back.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with schizophrenia presents to the emergency department with severe neck stiffness and an inability to move his head, which developed shortly after receiving an intramuscular antipsychotic injection. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Diphenhydramine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotics can be seen within minutes of receiving an injectable antipsychotic (also with oral antipsychotic). It is characterized by sudden contraction of a muscle group and can lead to symptoms like torticollis (twisting of the neck), oculogyric crisis (deviation of eyeballs), opisthotonos (extreme arching of the back), trismus (contraction of jaw muscles) or other dystonic reactions. Treatment of acute dystonia involves immediate administration of parental anticholinergics such as benztropine, promethazine, or diphenhydramine. To prevent acute dystonia, prophylactic use of oral anticholinergics is suggested while prescribing typical antipsychotics.
  • ➤ earliest side effect
  • ➤ sudden contraction
  • ➤ torticollis
  • ➤ oculogyric crisis
  • ➤ opisthotonos
  • ➤ anticholinergics

References:

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of intense fear, chest tightness, palpitations, dizziness, and sweating. She reports that these episodes occur unpredictably and peak within minutes. Which of the following is most consistent with a diagnosis of a panic attack?

options.label: A
options.text: Symptoms triggered by a specific phobia

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms peak within 10 minutes and resolve within 30 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: Persistent symptoms lasting for several hours

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Symptoms peak within 10 minutes and resolve within 30 minutes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A panic attack is an acute attack of intense anxiety accompanied by a feeling of impending doom . The symptoms during the panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain , choking sensations , dizziness, and feelings of unreality (depersonalization or derealization). Along with these physical symptoms, there is also a fear of dying , losing control or going mad . For immediate relief from panic attacks, benzodiazepines are preferred.
  • ➤ feeling of impending doom
  • ➤ chest pain
  • ➤ choking sensations
  • ➤ fear of dying
  • ➤ losing control
  • ➤ going mad

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with persistent worry about multiple aspects of his life, including work performance and financial stability, for the past eight months. He reports difficulty sleeping, irritability, and feeling on edge most of the time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Generalized anxiety disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Generalized Anxiety Disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety which is generalized and persistent and is not restricted to any particular situation (also called freely floating anxiety ) and excessive worries. Patients are anxious about almost everything. This anxiety and worry is associated with the physical symptoms such as: restlessness, fatigue, poor concentration, irritability, muscle tension and insomnia. Treatment includes pharmacotherapy (SSRIs, benzodiazepines, buspirone and venlafaxine) and psychotherapy (CBT, supportive psychotherapy).
  • ➤ freely floating anxiety
  • ➤ excessive worries.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 405.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of inability to move her right arm after a heated argument with her partner. Neurological examination and imaging studies are normal, and no organic cause is identified. She appears unconcerned about her symptoms and is otherwise emotionally stable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conversion disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conversion disorder (ICD-11 uses the term ‘Dissociative neurological symptom disorder’) is characterized by symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found. The symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles. Patients may have ‘ la belle indifference ’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g. A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom. An important d/d of conversion disorder is acute intermittent porphyria
  • ➤ la belle indifference

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 454.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman from a rural area is brought to the clinic after episodes of unresponsiveness and unusual behavior during which she appears to be in a trance-like state. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dissociative disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociative disorders involve disruptions in consciousness, memory, or identity and are often triggered by psychological stress . Trance-like states, unresponsiveness, and amnesia following emotionally stressful events are hallmarks of dissociative disorders and require careful evaluation and treatment focused on the underlying psychological stressors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of unresolved grief attends a therapy session where he expresses intense emotions about the loss of his parent and reports feeling relieved afterward. This emotional release is best described as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Catharsis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Consider the following statements about dissociative identity disorder (DID): Statement 1: DID is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states that recurrently take control of the individual’s behavior. Statement 2: The condition is strongly associated with a history of severe childhood trauma or abuse. Statement 3: Symptoms such as amnesia, depersonalization, and derealization are common in DID. Statement 4: Pharmacological treatment is the primary intervention for managing DID. Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Statements 1 and 2 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociative identity disorder (Multiple personality disorder) is characterized by the presence of two or more personalities (or “personality states” or ‘alters’) in an individual, out of which, only one is evident at a time. Usually, the different personalities are completely unaware of each other’s existence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of alcohol dependence is brought to the emergency department with confusion, agitation, sweating, and tremors three days after abruptly stopping alcohol consumption. On examination, he is disoriented, has a fever of 101°F, and reports seeing insects crawling on the walls. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%. The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity. It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: The phenomenon, where impairment is greater at a given blood alcohol concentration during the ascending phase than during the descending phase, is best described as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mellanby phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mellanby phenomenon illustrates phase-dependent tolerance, where individuals experience greater impairment during the rising phase of blood alcohol concentration compared to the falling phase at the same concentration. This is an example of acute alcohol tolerance.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with confusion, unsteady gait, and involuntary eye movements. Laboratory tests show hypomagnesemia and mild anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this condition?

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous thiamine followed by glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy is treated with intravenous thiamine administered before glucose , followed by supportive measures such as magnesium and addressing nutritional deficiencies. Prompt intervention is critical to prevent irreversible damage or progression to Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine visit. The physician is concerned about his alcohol consumption and decides to screen him using the CAGE questionnaire. Which of the following is assessed by this tool?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CAGE questionnaire is a brief tool used to screen for potential alcohol use problems.It consists of four questions, with the acronym "CAGE" representing key words from each question:
  • ➤ C: Have you ever felt you ought to Cut down on your drinking? A: Have people Annoyed you by criticizing your drinking? G: Have you ever felt bad or Guilty about your drinking? E: Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or to get rid of a hangover ( Eye-opener )?

  • ➤ Cut down
  • ➤ A: Have people Annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
  • ➤ Annoyed
  • ➤ G: Have you ever felt bad or Guilty about your drinking?

  • ➤ E: Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or to get rid of a hangover ( Eye-opener )?

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found agitated and hyperactive at a party. He has dilated pupils, tachycardia (HR: 120 bpm), hypertension (BP: 160/100 mmHg), and reports chest pain. On further questioning, he admits to using a substance earlier in the evening to "stay awake and energized." Which of the following substances is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine intoxication is characterized by euphoria, pupillary dilatation, tachycardia, hypertension, and sweating. Acute intoxication with moderate to high doses of cocaine may be associated with paranoid ideations , auditory hallucinations, and visual illusions. The patients also occasionally report tactile hallucinations (feeling of insects crawling under the skin), also known as cocaine bugs . (also known as formication and magnan phenomenon ).
  • ➤ paranoid ideations
  • ➤ cocaine bugs
  • ➤ formication
  • ➤ magnan phenomenon

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 304.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the clinic seeking help to quit cannabis use. He reports daily use for the past three years and unsuccessful attempts to quit, despite experiencing negative effects on his academics and relationships. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial approach to manage cannabis use disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cognitive-behavioral therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective first-line treatment for cannabis use disorder. It helps patients develop coping skills, avoid high-risk situations for drug use, and address underlying psychological issues contributing to substance use. Pharmacological treatments like naltrexone, bupropion, and disulfiram are not indicated for cannabis use disorder.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 289.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is prescribed varenicline to assist with smoking cessation. He asks how the medication works. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of varenicline?

options.text: Partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to excessive time spent playing online video games. questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Symptoms causing significant impairment in functioning

This condition highlights the importance of addressing behavioral addictions in clinical practice.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about opioid overdose: Statement 1: Opioid overdose leads to respiratory depression due to suppression of the medullary respiratory centers. questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is diagnosed with moderate Alzhiemer’s disease. She was prescribed on a medication, which acts by blocking glutamate receptors. Which of the following is most likely medication?

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his family due to progressive memory loss, difficulty managing finances, and trouble navigating familiar places over the past year. questions.correct_answer: B. Significant impairment in one or more cognitive domains with interference in daily functioning

Ans. B) Significant impairment in one or more cognitive domains with interference in daily functioning

questions.text: Which type of dementia is most likely contraindicated for treatment with antipsychotics?

  • ➤ Recurrent visual hallucinations
  • ➤ visual hallucinations
  • ➤ Parkinsonian features (hence antipsychotics should be avoided)
  • ➤ Parkinsonian features

questions.text: A 70-year-old hospitalized woman becomes acutely confused, agitated, and disoriented after starting a new medication for pain management. Her vital signs are stable, and she has no history of dementia. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for her delirium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) New medication use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delirium is characterized by sudden onset & fluctuating course and presents with disturbances of consciousness (hallmark symptom), disorientation to time, place and person, perceptual disturbances like illusions and hallucinations, impairment of attention, memory disturbances (recent and immediate, remote is intact), agitation (or hypoactivity), autonomic disturbances, sleep-wake cycle disturbances and sundowning phenomenon. Causes include:
  • ➤ Medical and surgical disorders/in hospitalised patients. Hip fractures, open heart surgery, severe burns, infections like pneumonia, postoperative patients, critically ill patients Alcohol and sedatives withdrawal On multiple medications (especially with anticholinergic actions) Sensory deprivation (e.g. Black patch delirium after cataract surgery)
  • ➤ Medical and surgical disorders/in hospitalised patients.
  • ➤ Hip fractures, open heart surgery, severe burns, infections like pneumonia, postoperative patients, critically ill patients
  • ➤ Alcohol and sedatives withdrawal

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his family due to significant personality changes over the past six months. questions.text: Match the following:

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman frequently experiences emotional outbursts and unstable interpersonal relationships. She often describes people in her life as either "all good" or "all bad," depending on recent interactions. Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains this behavior?

questions.text: A 40-year-old man avoids social interactions and frequently accuses his coworkers of conspiring against him without evidence. He is overly suspicious of others’ motives and interprets neutral comments as critical or threatening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following represents a key change in the classification of personality disorders in the ICD-11 compared to the ICD-10?

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient, brought in by the police, is being assessed for his personality. He is presented with cards featuring images similar to the one provided below. Which method is being employed for his personality assessment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rorschach Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rorschach Test is a projective test that uses inkblot images to assess personality structure and emotional functioning. It provides insights into subconscious thoughts and feelings and is commonly used in psychoanalytic and psychodynamic assessments .
  • ➤ Rorschach Test
  • ➤ inkblot images
  • ➤ psychoanalytic and psychodynamic assessments

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 58-59.
